00017 package WeBWorK::Utils::FilterRecords;
00018 use base qw(Exporter);
00019 
00020 use WeBWorK::Utils qw(sortByName);
00021 
00022 =head1 NAME
00023 
00024 WeBWorK::Utils::FilterRecords - utilities for sorting database records.
00025 
00026 =head1 SYNOPSIS
00027 
00028  use WeBWorK::Utils::FilterRecords qw/getFiltersForClass/;
00029  
00030  # get a list of sorts
00031  my ($FiltersRef, $FilterLabelsRef) = getFiltersForClass(@Users);
00032  my @filters      = @$filtersRef;      # filter names
00033  my %FilterLabels = %$FilterLabelsRef; # suitable for CGI's "-labels" parameter
00034 
00035  use WeBWorK::Utils::FilterRecords qw/FilterRecords/;
00036  
00037  # start with a list of records
00038  my @Users = $db->getUsers($db->listUsers);
00039  
00040  # sort the records using a preset
00041  @FilteredUsers = FilterRecords({preset=>"none"}, @Users);
00042  
00043  # or provide a custom sort
00044  @FilteredUsers = FilterRecords({fields=>[qw/section /]}, @Users);
00045 
00046 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00047 
00048 This module provides record filtering functions, and a collection of preset filters
00049 for the standard WeBWorK record classes. Filters are specified by a list
00050 of field names. Records that match the current user in the specified field will be 
00051 allowed through
00052 
00053 =cut
00054 
00055 use strict;
00056 use warnings;
00057 use Carp;
00058 our @EXPORT    = ();
00059 our @EXPORT_OK = qw(
00060     getFiltersForClass
00061     filterRecords
00062 );
00063 
00064 #use constant PRESET_FILTERS => {
00065 #   "WeBWorK::DB::Record::User" => {
00066 #       "all" => {
00067 #           name => "List all available students",
00068 #           fields => [ qw// ],
00069 #       },
00070 #   },
00071 #};
00072 
00073 
00074 =head1 FUNCTIONS
00075 
00076 =over
00077 
00078 =item getFiltersForClass($class)
00079 
00080 Given the name of a record class, returns the preset filters available for that
00081 class.
00082 
00083 The return value consists of a two-element list. The first element is a
00084 reference to a list of filter names. The second element is a reference to a hash
00085 mapping filter names to string descriptions.
00086 
00087 Together, these two lists are suitable for passing to the C<-values> and
00088 C<-labels> parameters of several CGI module methods, i.e. popup_menu(),
00089 scrolling_list(), checkbox_group(), and radio_group().
00090 
00091 =cut
00092 
00093 sub getFiltersForClass {
00094     my (@Records) = @_;
00095 
00096     my (%sections, %recitations);
00097     my (@names,%labels);
00098     push @names, "all";
00099     $labels{all} = "Display all possible records";
00100     
00101     if (ref $Records[0] eq "WeBWorK::DB::Record::User"){
00102         foreach my $user (@Records){
00103             $sections{$user->section}++;
00104             $recitations{$user->recitation}++;
00105         }
00106     
00107         if (scalar(keys %sections) > 1) {
00108           foreach my $sec (sortByName(undef, keys %sections)){
00109             push @names, "section:$sec";
00110             if ($sec ne ""){
00111                 $labels{"section:$sec"} = "Display section $sec";
00112             } else {
00113                 $labels{"section:$sec"} = "Display section <blank>";
00114             }
00115           }
00116         }
00117 
00118         if (scalar(keys %recitations) > 1) {
00119           foreach my $rec (sortByName(undef, keys %recitations)){
00120             push @names, "recitation:$rec";
00121             if ($rec ne ""){
00122                 $labels{"recitation:$rec"} = "Display recitation $rec";
00123             } else {
00124                     $labels{"recitation:$rec"} = "Display recitation <blank>";
00125             }
00126           }
00127         }
00128     }
00129     return ( \@names, \%labels );
00130 }
00131 
00132 =item sortRecords(\%options, @Records)
00133 
00134 Given a sort specification (or the name of a preset format) and a list of
00135 records, returns a list of the same records in order according to the sort.
00136 
00137 %options can consist of either:
00138 
00139  preset => the name of a preset format listed by getFormatsForClass()
00140 
00141 or:
00142 
00143  fields => a reference to a list of fields in the records' class
00144 
00145 If C<preset> is given, and its value does not match any known preset but I<is>
00146 the name of a field in the record class, the records will be sorted by that
00147 field.
00148 
00149 If C<fields> is given, the records are sorted according to the specified fields.
00150 If multiple fields are specified, the second field is is consulted if two
00151 records are found to have identical first fields, and so on.
00152 
00153 =cut
00154 
00155 # DBFIXME filtering should happen in the database (WHERE clauses)
00156 sub filterRecords {
00157     my ($options, @Records) = @_;
00158     
00159     # nothing to do
00160     return () unless @Records;
00161     
00162     # get class info (we assume that the records are all of the same type)
00163     
00164     my %options = %$options;
00165     
00166     my @filtersToUse = @{$options{filter}};
00167 
00168     if (grep {$_ eq "all"} @filtersToUse) {return @Records;}
00169     
00170     my @GoodRecords = ();
00171     foreach my $record (@Records){
00172     foreach my $fil (@filtersToUse){
00173         my ($name, $value) = split(/:/, $fil);
00174         #warn "filter = $fil";
00175         #warn "name = $name";
00176         #warn "value = $value";
00177         #warn "section = $record->section";
00178 #       my @data = split(/::/, $record);
00179         if ($record->$name eq $value) {push @GoodRecords, $record}
00180     }
00181     }
00182     return @GoodRecords;
00183 }
00184 
00185 =back
00186 
00187 =head1 BUGS
00188 
00189 No provision for case-insensitive, descending, or numeric sorting.
00190 
00191 No provision for programmatic sorts. While a one-time programmatic sort can be
00192 done easily without using this module, programmatic preset sorts would be
00193 useful, i.e. for intelligent sorting of set IDs.
00194 
00195 The fields being compared cannot contain nulls, because of the way packed keys
00196 are being generated.
00197 
00198 =cut
00199 
00200 1;
